items.prompt: Drain the fuel selector valve on the floorboard and turn the selector to the proper tank. Be sure the drain returns to "Off" position and that the pull ring is properly positioned in the cavity provided.
Power Boost control in filtered air (OFF) position
Green gear indicator light, "Low Vacuum" warning light, turn coordinator should come on
(Hot start, alternate cold start, and flooded start procedures moved to Abnormal section)
Conventional mag must be off to prevent kickback

Move mixture to full rich (forward) position for three seconds and return to idle cutoff (aft). Do not keep the mixture control in the full rich position more than a few seconds with the boost pump on to avoid flooding the engine.
In extremely cold weather it may be necessary to provide additional priming to the engine by holding mixture control in the full rich position a few seconds longer than usual.
When engine fires turn on MAG switch.
Should be alive within 10 sec. If more than 30 immediate shutdown.

Warm up engine at 1000-1200 RPM. Avoid prolonged idling at low engine speeds as this practice may result in fouled spark plugs. Engine is warm enough for take-off when it can develop full RPM and the throttle can be opened without backfiring or skipping of the engine or the throttle can be opened without a reduction in oil pressure.
If needed insert updated database card.
Check EDM and GTN650 for proper fuel quantity. Refill if necessary
If no ATIS information available, set pressure in Kollsman window so altimeter reads field elevation.
When stopped, head airplane into the wind.
Operate the engine on the ground only with the propeller in high RPM setting (control forward).
Keep mixture "full rich" (control forward) per the POH.
Do not overheat engine by prolonged ground running. Monitor the cylinder head temperature gauge.
Check manifold pressure gauge and tachometer for readings proportional to engine power
Check rate of climb (vertical speed indicator, VSI), airspeed indicator (ASI), and turn and bank indicator (turn coordinator, TC) for zero readings
Check artificial horizon (attitude indicator, AI) and HSI for proper orientation
Test gear indicator and vacuum warning lights
If one magneto runs rough, see Clear Fouled Plugs under Abnormal checklist.

Exercise the propeller at 1800-2000 RPM by pulling the propeller control to the "full-out" position. After the tachometer has shown a drop-off of 100 RPM, push the propeller to the "full-in" position.
At 1200 RPM or greater, operation of any electrical equipment should give an indication
The intermediate mark in the pointer range is the normal take-off setting for the trim control
Set the flap-shaped control (adjacent to the flap handle) in the down position. Pump flap handle twice.
Check other lights if flight is at night
ATC IFR ground  Clearance as necessary.  Disconnect iPad Bluetooth to use phone audio.
(Short field takeoff procedure moved to Abnormal section)
Move the throttle to the full open position slowly.
Apply back pressure at about 65-75 MPH airspeed.
When the M20 breaks ground, it will tend to "rock" into a nose-high attitude. To compensate for this tendency, relax some of the elevator back pressure as the nose wheel leaves the ground.
For best results and a smoother take-off, do not allow the nose of the M20 to lift above the horizon during take-off.

After some practice, you will find that you can make your smoothest take-offs by applying elevator back pressure as flying speed is approached then slowly reducing the back pressure as you feel the nose wheel lifting from the ground. This will allow the aircraft to fly smoothly from the runway without any abrupt change in pitch attitude.
Apply brakes to stop wheel rotation
Place the flap control in the up position (raised by spring / air pressure)
Trim nose down to level flight
Recommended the engine *not* be operated at cruise in range 2150-2300 RPM.
Set the mixture control for the fuel/air ratio desired. This is accomplished by use of the exhaust gas temperature indicator on the right side of the panel.

For best economy, lean the mixture by turning the control counter-clockwise until the indicator shows a peak (maximum) temperature and starts to decrease. Continue leaning until the temperature drops 25°F minimum from the peak.
To obtain a best power (maximum airspeed) setting, lean to peak temperature and then enrich the mixture (turn control clockwise) until the indicator shows a 100°F drop from peak temperature.
Do not lean the mixture at power settings above 75% rated power.
Operation of the mixture control should be slow enough to account for the slight lag in the EGT instrument.
Note Zulu time and tach time for each switch, per tank. Recommend 30/60/60 switching.

POH: After take-off with both tanks full, use one tank only until one hour of fuel depleted, then switch to second tank and record the time of switch-over. Use all the fuel in the second tank. Then, the time of fuel remaining in the first tank is the time it took to deplete the second tank, less one hour. However, this will be correct only if the cruise altitude and power setting remain unchanged.
First, increase engine speed (RPM) by means of the propeller control.
Second, increase manifold pressure by means of the throttle.
First, reduce manifold pressure by means of the throttle.
Second, decrease engine speed (RPM) by means of the propeller control.

When full throttle has been used and additional power is desired, the Power Boost control may be pulled out, provided the atmosphere is free of visible dust. This will allow the engine airflow to bypass the filter and provide approximately one inch Hg additional manifold pressure.
Push control in to close Power Boost ram air intake
By reducing manifold pressure below cruise setting and retaining cruise speed, a let-down can be made without excessive engine cooling.
Below 120 MPH. Green Indicator (if not illuminated, can swap in red "gear up" indicator).
Fly the base leg at 90 MPH.
Apply below 100 MPH. Flap control in down position. 4 1/2 pumps for full deflection. As flaps are extended, aircraft will become nose heavy.
Roll the trim back to the aircraft will glide hands-off at approximately 80 MPH.
The addition of a slight amount of power will flatten out the glide considerably.
Begin your flare-out for landing closer to the ground than you ordinarily would, for two reasons:
1. The Executive 21 sits lower to the ground than most aircraft; and
2. The Executive 21 requires very little altitude to make a transition from a glide to a landing attitude. A slight addition of back pressure is sufficient to stop the rate of descent.

It is recommended that full flaps be used on all landings, because of the added visibility over the nose that it affords. However, the use of full flaps tends to make an aircraft nose-heavy, and it is therefore necessary to roll the trim well back to make a good landing.
As engine stops firing, retard throttle all the way out to eliminate engine vibration (POH)
802 lbs  =  Payload with Fuel ½ Fuel12.2 gph  =  Fuel Consumption @ 75% Power (2600RPM, 22" HG @ 7500', ~183mph)
64 gal  =  Total Fuel Capacity (26 per side)
Vx              94 MPH = Best Angle of Climb SpeedVy            105 MPH = Best Rate of Climb Speed
Vbest l/d 107 MPH = Best Glide (Lift/Drag), Flaps Up/Down
Vs              68 MPH = Stall Speed, Normal ConfigurationVso            62 MPH = Stall Speed, Landing ConfigurationVfe           105 MPH = Maximum flap Extension Speed
Vlo           120 MPH = Maximum Landing Gear Operation
Va            135 MPH = Maneuvering Speed (at Gross Weight)
Vno          175 MPH = Maximum Structural Cruising Speed
65 MPH = Short Field Take Off, Flaps 15°
90 MPH = Normal Landing Approach, Flaps Up
"I suggest flying the pattern at 100 MPH downwind, 90 MPH on base, 80 MPH on final, and 70-75 MPH over the numbers."
If a tank runs dry and the engine loses power:
Restarting with advanced throttle may cause engine over speeding and can lead to mechanical malfunction.
When engine fires, release starter key and firmly (but not rapidly move mixture control to full rich
After engine is running, lean mixture control for smooth idle
Engine should start after a couple of rotations
Expect about 15-20 blades before the engine fires
When the engine fires, smoothly (not rapidly) move mixture control to full rich
After idling, lean the mixture for smooth operation on the ground and during taxi
Run for a few seconds until fuel pressure indicator is in the green, then turn off
Crank and slowly advance mixture. It will catch usually before you are 1/2 way to full rich. Once it does, go full rich.
Slowly pull the throttle back towards idle as the engine is turning over with the starter engaged.
When the throttle is reduced to about 1/2-3/4 way towards the idle position, the engine should fire after the throttle hits the position for the perfect fuel/air mixture for starting.
When the engine fires, smoothly increase the mixture to full rich
After idling for a while, lean the mixture for smooth operation on the ground and during taxi
As the engine is "propped," hold the magneto switch in the "start" position to operate the starter vibrator and furnish a retarded spark to the engine.
Do not push the magneto switch. This engages the starter.
When the engine starts, release the switch to the "Both" position.
If, during the magneto check in the run-up, one magneto runs rough, follow this procedure.
Allow engine to run at 800 RPM for a minute
Slowly increase the power to 2200 RPM
This operation will usually burn out the carbon deposits and allow the magnetos to check properly.
This checklist came from the M20B...
Restarting with advanced throttle may cause engine over speeding and can lead to mechanical malfunction.
If engine failure is caused by fuel exhaustion, power will not be regained after tanks are switched until empty fuel lines are filled. This may take up to 10 sec.
AVIATE ...... Immediately pitch for Best Glide Speed
NAVIGATE ... Find a place to land and fly toward it
RESTART ....... Switch Fuel Tanks, Fuel Pump on, Mixture Full Rich, cycle Mags.
GET HELP ...... Switch Transponder to 7700 then Transmit MAYDAY on 121.5
SECURE PLANE ..... Fuel Selector OFF, Fuel Pump OFF, Mixture IDLE OFF, and Mags OFF... Open Door
Restarting with advanced throttle may cause engine over speeding and can lead to mechanical malfunction.
AVIATE ...... Immediately pitch for Best Glide Speed
NAVIGATE ... Find a place to land and fly toward it
RESTART ....... Switch Fuel Tanks, Fuel Pump on, Mixture Full Rich, cycle Mags.
GET HELP ...... Switch Transponder to 7700 then Transmit MAYDAY on 121.5
SECURE PLANE ..... Fuel Selector OFF, Fuel Pump OFF, Mixture IDLE OFF, and Mags OFF... Open Door
If engine failure is caused by fuel exhaustion, power will not be regained after tanks are switched until empty fuel lines are filled. This may take up to 10 sec.
